newsitem.title: CANADA: Inco sees 15 mln lbs less nickel in 1996.
newsitem.headline: Inco sees 15 mln lbs less nickel in 1996.

text.p: Inco Ltd's 1996 nickel production will likely be about 15 million pounds lower than in 1995 because of a labor dispute in Manitoba and a broken furnace in Indonesia, the company said on Tuesday.
Total production for the year was expected to be 415 million pounds of nickel, compared to about 430 million pounds last year, Inco president Scott Hand told a conference call.
"Production was going pretty well, indeed a lot better than last year," he said.
But the third-quarter production problems hurt, he said.

"We will come out around 415 millon pounds, affected primarily by the furnace eruption at PT Inco -- which will reduce their production by around seven million pounds -- and by the stoppage in Manitoba, (which is) another six million pounds or so," Hand said.
Inco locked out its workers in Thompson, Manitoba for 14 days this autumn over a contract dispute.
The company lost the use of one of three furnaces at its Indonesian facilities after an explosion.
The accident is under investigation and has not hampered the budget or expansion schedule in Indonesia, he said.
The coming year will likely bring better nickel prices than the "disappointing" 1996 levels, said John Jones, assistant vice-president of marketing.
Supply and demand in the nickel market had been in balance for most of the year, he said.
But the balance was poised to change with stronger economies and rising stainless steel demand expected in the fourth quarter, he added.
"We are guardedly optimistic going into the next year."
Meanwhile, the company said it discovered some "interesting" mineralization at its Voisey's Bay property.
Exploration exposed mineralization to the east and south of the Eastern Deeps area at the remote Labrador project, said Bob Horn, vice-president of exploration.
The company also found high nickel and copper grades to the west of its Western Extension deposit, Horn said.
"We have a very good chance of increasing our reserves in that area," he said.
Inco also found mineralization to the north, but Horn said it was too early to release any numbers.
Inco was also hoping to grow in Brazil and Turkey, he said.
